test/performance/RAMLibrary not portable

content.raw:
[test/performance/RAMLibrary.hh](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/de1302de781064de8b4fa3a078f20f11852ca823/test/performance/RAMLibrary.hh?at=default) is currently used for testing memory usage in the performance tests, but it is not portable, as it currently parses `/proc/meminfo` for Linux, but this is not available for OSX or Windows.

@wwoodall suggested the python library [psutil](http://code.google.com/p/psutil/), which is portable to Linux, OSX and Windows. Since it's relatively small, we could consider including it in the `test/performance` folder.
content.html:
test/performance/RAMLibrary.hh is currently used for testing memory usage in the performance tests, but it is not portable, as it currently parses /proc/meminfo for Linux, but this is not available for OSX or Windows.

@wwoodall suggested the python library psutil, which is portable to Linux, OSX and Windows. Since it's relatively small, we could consider including it in the test/performance folder.

values.title: Integration test for OpenAL

content.raw:
**Quote from pull request #648**

I was thinking about how to unit test the sound, more correctly speaking, integration-test the sound, since a unit test will imply use a stub for the sounds system. This could be an option, just create an stub to replace audio library calls, which will allow to test if correct orders where sent to the sound system (while not actually checking if something sounds or not).

Real integration test with native audio could be a bit harder, especially thinking on portability issues and related to something else being played while test is running.

values.title: Gazebo's installed CMake configuration should export Boost and Protobuf libs

content.raw:
When compiling a client program against Gazebo's libraries, I have to explicitly link against some Boost libraries, even though my code doesn't call Boost.  This is also done in the [listener example](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/b2d2cf062c2b09177badd4a63a1aa5a4e6791485/examples/stand_alone/listener/CMakeLists.txt?at=default#cl-8).  It's (some of) Gazebo's libs that depend on Boost, so Gazebo should add them to `GAZEBO_LIBRARIES` for use by client programs.

Same goes for protobuf.
content.html:
When compiling a client program against Gazebo's libraries, I have to explicitly link against some Boost libraries, even though my code doesn't call Boost. This is also done in the listener example. It's (some of) Gazebo's libs that depend on Boost, so Gazebo should add them to GAZEBO_LIBRARIES for use by client programs.

Same goes for protobuf.

values.title: Slow client can cause publisher to stop producing data

content.html:
Run Gazebo with the following world:

<?xml version="1.0" ?>
<sdf version='1.4'>
  <world name="default">
    <model name="model">
      <link name="link">
        <sensor name="camera" type="camera"/>
      </link>
    </model>
  </world>
</sdf>

Compile (e.g., use the listener example CMakeLists.txt) and run the following test program:

#include <gazebo/transport/transport.hh>
#include <gazebo/msgs/msgs.hh>
#include <gazebo/gazebo.hh>

void cb(ConstImageStampedPtr &_msg)
{ 
  std::cout << "got message" << std::endl;
  // The following pause will cause data to backup, eventually
  // making the publisher stop producing data.
  pause();
}

int main(int _argc, char **_argv)
{ 
  gazebo::load(_argc, _argv);
  gazebo::run();
  gazebo::transport::NodePtr node(new gazebo::transport::Node());
  node->Init();
  gazebo::transport::SubscriberPtr sub = node->Subscribe("~/model/link/camera/image", cb);
  while (true)
    gazebo::common::Time::MSleep(10);
  gazebo::transport::fini();
}

It'll get one message, then block, presumably causing data to back up in the socket and then the publisher queue. At some point, the server will print this message:

Warning [Publisher.cc:144] Queue limit reached for topic /gazebo/default/model/link/camera/image, deleting message. This warning is printed only once.

After that, the publisher doesn't send out any more data. Kill and restart the test program and it won't get any messages. Same result if you open the Topic Visualization window and try to show the camera topic.

values.title: UNIT_MainWindow_TEST fails in Jenkins but not on local machine

content.raw:
Here's an [example test failure](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo-gpu/job/gazebo-default-devel-quantal-amd64-gpu-nvidia/183/testReport/%28root%29/MainWindow_TEST/Wireframe/) with error message:
~~~
Unknown file:0 :: Received a fatal error.
~~~

The strange thing is that this test passes on my local machine.

I have been able to see failures of this test in my overnight testing with the [gz_build_test.bash script](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/b2d2cf062c2b09177badd4a63a1aa5a4e6791485/tools/gz_build_test.bash?at=default). They have the following console output:
~~~
61: Test command: /tmp/gazebo_build/source/build/gazebo/gui/UNIT_MainWindow_TEST "-xml" "-o" "/tmp/gazebo_build/source/build/test_results/UNIT_MainWindow_TEST.xml"
61: Test timeout computed to be: 240
61: 
61: Msg Waiting for masterMsg Connected to gazebo master @ http://127.0.0.1:11345
61: Msg Publicized address: 192.168.1.183
61: Dbg AvgPrewireframe [0] AvgPostWireframe[0]
61: SharePercentChange[1.40118] ShareMaxPercentChange[2]
61: ResPercentChange[3.06243]ResMaxPercentChange[4]
~~~
For this case, I believe the failure is related to the line that prints the average color before and after wireframe is turned on:
~~~
61: Dbg AvgPrewireframe [0] AvgPostWireframe[0]
~~~
since there is a [QVerify statement](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/b2d2cf062c2b09177badd4a63a1aa5a4e6791485/gazebo/gui/MainWindow_TEST.cc?at=default#cl-127) that expects these values to be different.

In the morning, the script is still running, and once I log in to the machine with the monitor turned on, the test starts passing. So perhaps some hardware component is disabled when the screen is turned off.
content.html:
Here's an example test failure with error message:

Unknown file:0 :: Received a fatal error.

The strange thing is that this test passes on my local machine.

I have been able to see failures of this test in my overnight testing with the gz_build_test.bash script. They have the following console output:

61: Test command: /tmp/gazebo_build/source/build/gazebo/gui/UNIT_MainWindow_TEST "-xml" "-o" "/tmp/gazebo_build/source/build/test_results/UNIT_MainWindow_TEST.xml"
61: Test timeout computed to be: 240
61: 
61: Msg Waiting for masterMsg Connected to gazebo master @ http://127.0.0.1:11345
61: Msg Publicized address: 192.168.1.183
61: Dbg AvgPrewireframe [0] AvgPostWireframe[0]
61: SharePercentChange[1.40118] ShareMaxPercentChange[2]
61: ResPercentChange[3.06243]ResMaxPercentChange[4]

For this case, I believe the failure is related to the line that prints the average color before and after wireframe is turned on:

61: Dbg AvgPrewireframe [0] AvgPostWireframe[0]

since there is a QVerify statement that expects these values to be different.

In the morning, the script is still running, and once I log in to the machine with the monitor turned on, the test starts passing. So perhaps some hardware component is disabled when the screen is turned off.

values.title: Incorrect frame used in ODEJoint::GetForceTorque

content.raw:
When the parent link of a joint is the world, [ODEJoint::GetForceTorque](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/b2d2cf062c2b09177badd4a63a1aa5a4e6791485/gazebo/physics/ode/ODEJoint.cc?at=default#cl-1057) uses an incorrect frame for the wrench acting on the world link. It should be expressed in the world frame, but it is currently being expressed in the child frame.

Thanks to @jlee02 for finding this bug.
content.html:
When the parent link of a joint is the world, ODEJoint::GetForceTorque uses an incorrect frame for the wrench acting on the world link. It should be expressed in the world frame, but it is currently being expressed in the child frame.

Thanks to @jlee02 for finding this bug.

values.title: Race condition in `gazebo -h` and occasional manpages test failure

content.raw:
The `gazebo` executable works by forking twice and executing 'gzserver' and `gzclient` instances in the forked processes with the same input arguments (see [gazebo_main.cc](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/0332ac8db9b76a8025d8c6ed2fa0bee3bb526836/gazebo/gazebo_main.cc?at=default#cl-78)). In theory, running `gazebo -h` could show the help message for both `gzserver` and `gzclient`. There's currently a race condition, however, that causes it to only show one message, usually that of `gzserver`. It is possible for the `gzclient` help message to come up (as observed in [this Jenkins test failure](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-default-devel-quantal-amd64/305/testReport/junit/%28root%29/ManTest/gazebo/)).

Inserting MSleep calls can illustrate the race condition. For example, with the following patch
~~~
diff -r 0332ac8db9b7 gazebo/Server.cc
--- a/gazebo/Server.cc	Fri Aug 23 05:35:32 2013 -0700
+++ b/gazebo/Server.cc	Fri Aug 23 14:06:38 2013 -0700
@@ -139,6 +139,7 @@
 
   if (this->vm.count("help"))
   {
+    common::Time::MSleep(300);
     this->PrintUsage();
     std::cerr << v_desc << "\n";
     return false;
~~~
I see the following from `gazebo -h`:
~~~
$ gazebo -h
gzclient -- Gazebo GUI Client

`gzclient` [options]

Gazebo GUI client which allows visualization and user interaction.

Options:
  -q [ --quiet ]          Reduce output to stdout.
  -h [ --help ]           Produce this help message.
  -g [ --gui-plugin ] arg Load a plugin.

gzserver -- Run the Gazebo server.

`gzserver` [options] <world_file>

Gazebo server runs simulation and handles commandline options, starts a Master, runs World update and sensor generation loops.

Options:
  -q [ --quiet ]                Reduce output to stdout.
  -h [ --help ]                 Produce this help message.
  -u [ --pause ]                Start the server in a paused state.
  -e [ --physics ] arg          Specify a physics engine (ode|bullet).
  -p [ --play ] arg             Play a log file.
  -r [ --record ]               Record state data.
  --record_encoding arg (=zlib) Compression encoding format for log data 
                                (zlib|bz2|txt).
  --record_path arg             Absolute path in which to store state data
  --seed arg                    Start with a given random number seed.
  --iters arg                   Number of iterations to simulate.
  -s [ --server-plugin ] arg    Load a plugin.

~~~
content.html:
The gazebo executable works by forking twice and executing 'gzserver' and gzclient instances in the forked processes with the same input arguments (see gazebo_main.cc). In theory, running gazebo -h could show the help message for both gzserver and gzclient. There's currently a race condition, however, that causes it to only show one message, usually that of gzserver. It is possible for the gzclient help message to come up (as observed in this Jenkins test failure).

Inserting MSleep calls can illustrate the race condition. For example, with the following patch

diff -r 0332ac8db9b7 gazebo/Server.cc
--- a/gazebo/Server.cc  Fri Aug 23 05:35:32 2013 -0700
+++ b/gazebo/Server.cc  Fri Aug 23 14:06:38 2013 -0700
@@ -139,6 +139,7 @@

   if (this->vm.count("help"))
   {
+    common::Time::MSleep(300);
     this->PrintUsage();
     std::cerr << v_desc << "\n";
     return false;

I see the following from gazebo -h:

$ gazebo -h
gzclient -- Gazebo GUI Client

`gzclient` [options]

Gazebo GUI client which allows visualization and user interaction.

Options:
  -q [ --quiet ]          Reduce output to stdout.
  -h [ --help ]           Produce this help message.
  -g [ --gui-plugin ] arg Load a plugin.

gzserver -- Run the Gazebo server.

`gzserver` [options] <world_file>

Gazebo server runs simulation and handles commandline options, starts a Master, runs World update and sensor generation loops.

Options:
  -q [ --quiet ]                Reduce output to stdout.
  -h [ --help ]                 Produce this help message.
  -u [ --pause ]                Start the server in a paused state.
  -e [ --physics ] arg          Specify a physics engine (ode|bullet).
  -p [ --play ] arg             Play a log file.
  -r [ --record ]               Record state data.
  --record_encoding arg (=zlib) Compression encoding format for log data 
                                (zlib|bz2|txt).
  --record_path arg             Absolute path in which to store state data
  --seed arg                    Start with a given random number seed.
  --iters arg                   Number of iterations to simulate.
  -s [ --server-plugin ] arg    Load a plugin.

values.title: Model visuals freeze when using GUI tools

content.raw:
Occasionally the display of gazebo models will freeze when using the translate, rotate, and resize tools. There is different behavior depending on which order is used to select the tool and the model.

[This video](https://vimeo.com/73276986), shows a double pendulum model moved with the GUI translate tool.

First the model is selected, and the visuals continue to update. Then the translate tool is made active, and the visuals still continue to update. The model visuals freeze, when the user clicks and drags to translate the model.

After the click and drag operation, the model is unselected automatically, and the translate tool is still active. Selecting the model while the tool is active then causes the visuals to freeze, even without clicking and dragging.

The bug I'm focusing on is the freezing of visuals when selecting a model while the translate tool is active that occurs without clicking and dragging. Getting rid of the freeze during click and drag would be nice but is less urgent.
content.html:
Occasionally the display of gazebo models will freeze when using the translate, rotate, and resize tools. There is different behavior depending on which order is used to select the tool and the model.

This video, shows a double pendulum model moved with the GUI translate tool.

First the model is selected, and the visuals continue to update. Then the translate tool is made active, and the visuals still continue to update. The model visuals freeze, when the user clicks and drags to translate the model.

After the click and drag operation, the model is unselected automatically, and the translate tool is still active. Selecting the model while the tool is active then causes the visuals to freeze, even without clicking and dragging.

The bug I'm focusing on is the freezing of visuals when selecting a model while the translate tool is active that occurs without clicking and dragging. Getting rid of the freeze during click and drag would be nice but is less urgent.

values.title: Multi-parameter unit tests

content.raw:
We recently changed our syntax for instantiating physics tests using multiple physics engines by using the [INSTANTIATE_TEST_CASE_P syntax](http://code.google.com/p/googletest/wiki/AdvancedGuide#How_to_Write_Value-Parameterized_Tests) (see pull request #661). In pull request #672 (which was declined), there were a series of tests that act on several joint types. It was suggested by @_jrivero_ that we consider splitting each joint type into a separate test case. Currently ServerFixture is set up to receive a single `const char*` parameter ([see ServerFixture.hh:61](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/6d1e49939c05cefc71b410b01af289d4eeef6b62/test/ServerFixture.hh?at=default#cl-61)), but it would require a different setup to allow more parameters.

I've investigated the different options provided by gtest, and there is a very intriguing option in the Combine function (see [comments in gtest-param-test.h](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/6d1e49939c05cefc71b410b01af289d4eeef6b62/test/gtest/include/gtest/gtest-param-test.h?at=default#cl-1224)). If you use tuples in the template type (`tuple<T1, T2,...TN>`) then the Combine function will allow you to specify a list of parameters for each type, like `{"ode", "bullet", "simbody", "dart"}` for physics engine and `{"revolute","prismatic","ball","universal"}` for joint type, and it will instantiate all combinations of those parameters as test cases (the [Cartesian product](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cartesian_product) is apparently what they call it).

This requires `std::tuple`. I just tried compiling some `std::tuple` code examples, which required compiling with `-std=c++11` in both Linux and OSX. I'm going to try implementing this for a dummy test case and then for the tests from pull request #672.
content.html:
We recently changed our syntax for instantiating physics tests using multiple physics engines by using the INSTANTIATE_TEST_CASE_P syntax (see pull request #661). In pull request #672 (which was declined), there were a series of tests that act on several joint types. It was suggested by @jrivero that we consider splitting each joint type into a separate test case. Currently ServerFixture is set up to receive a single const char* parameter (see ServerFixture.hh:61), but it would require a different setup to allow more parameters.

I've investigated the different options provided by gtest, and there is a very intriguing option in the Combine function (see comments in gtest-param-test.h). If you use tuples in the template type (tuple<T1, T2,...TN>) then the Combine function will allow you to specify a list of parameters for each type, like {"ode", "bullet", "simbody", "dart"} for physics engine and {"revolute","prismatic","ball","universal"} for joint type, and it will instantiate all combinations of those parameters as test cases (the Cartesian product is apparently what they call it).

This requires std::tuple. I just tried compiling some std::tuple code examples, which required compiling with -std=c++11 in both Linux and OSX. I'm going to try implementing this for a dummy test case and then for the tests from pull request #672.

values.title: Strange contact behavior with ODE trimeshes

content.raw: The [drc_practice_road_course model](#!/osrf/gazebo_models/src/919329863397efbc33dcc2ea45c2d30d2ca560ce/drc_practice_road_course?at=drcpractice_road) exhibits very strange contact behavior. Spheres sometimes fall into the road surface, and the polaris wheels tend to sink through the ground.
content.html: The drc_practice_road_course model exhibits very strange contact behavior. Spheres sometimes fall into the road surface, and the polaris wheels tend to sink through the ground.

values.title: repeated SetAxis code in Joint.cc
typo in cmake config file

content.raw: [gazebo cmake config file](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/b53e50cdcd03f4f8c2214c53107879c4a77d4561/cmake/gazebo-config.cmake.in?at=default#cl-10) has extra `RARY_DIRS` typo.
content.html: gazebo cmake config file has extra RARY_DIRS typo.

values.title: cmake integration test doesn't test linking

content.raw:
We have a cmake integration test that builds a gazebo plugin, but it doesn't fully test linking since the [hello_world plugin](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/b53e50cdcd03f4f8c2214c53107879c4a77d4561/test/cmake/plugin/hello_world.cc?at=default) doesn't invoke any gazebo libraries.
~~~
$ ldd libhello_world.so 
	linux-vdso.so.1 =>  (0x00007fff1e7ff000)
	libboost_system.so.1.49.0 => /usr/lib/libboost_system.so.1.49.0 (0x00007f9874642000)
	libstdc++.so.6 => /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libstdc++.so.6 (0x00007f987433f000)
	libgcc_s.so.1 => /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libgcc_s.so.1 (0x00007f9874128000)
	libc.so.6 => /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libc.so.6 (0x00007f9873d69000)
	libm.so.6 => /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libm.so.6 (0x00007f9873a6d000)
	/lib64/ld-linux-x86-64.so.2 (0x00007f9874a84000)
~~~
Issue #824 may have been prevented with an improved test.
content.html:
We have a cmake integration test that builds a gazebo plugin, but it doesn't fully test linking since the hello_world plugin doesn't invoke any gazebo libraries.

$ ldd libhello_world.so 
    linux-vdso.so.1 =>  (0x00007fff1e7ff000)
    libboost_system.so.1.49.0 => /usr/lib/libboost_system.so.1.49.0 (0x00007f9874642000)
    libstdc++.so.6 => /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libstdc++.so.6 (0x00007f987433f000)
    libgcc_s.so.1 => /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libgcc_s.so.1 (0x00007f9874128000)
    libc.so.6 => /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libc.so.6 (0x00007f9873d69000)
    libm.so.6 => /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libm.so.6 (0x00007f9873a6d000)
    /lib64/ld-linux-x86-64.so.2 (0x00007f9874a84000)

Issue #824 may have been prevented with an improved test.

values.title: UNIT_Sensor_TEST and others depend on machine performance

content.raw: As discussed in pull request #685, there UNIT_Sensor_TEST has several [expectations on sensor update rate](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/8aae2b5461a08e799ae3dbf622e22310323fd7b8/gazebo/sensors/Sensor_TEST.cc#cl-88), which are influenced by machine performance. These should be in performance tests, not unit or integration tests. This test and probably others should be fixed.
content.html: As discussed in pull request #685, there UNIT_Sensor_TEST has several expectations on sensor update rate, which are influenced by machine performance. These should be in performance tests, not unit or integration tests. This test and probably others should be fixed.

values.title: gzserver incredibility long load time when gazebosim.org is down.

content.raw:
I believe this is my first time launching gzserver on this machine and gazebosim.org is down right now. 

It would be nice if gzserver could ping gazebosim.org before attempting to download models from the database and if pings fail, skip the download and launch immediately.

Although there's not really much that can be done without the sun and ground_plane, so perhaps it would also be nice if there was a local copy that could it could fall back to for the first run.

I believe this is my first time launching gzserver on this machine and gazebosim.org is down right now.

It would be nice if gzserver could ping gazebosim.org before attempting to download models from the database and if pings fail, skip the download and launch immediately.

Although there's not really much that can be done without the sun and ground_plane, so perhaps it would also be nice if there was a local copy that could it could fall back to for the first run.

values.title: Update ImuSensor to use Sensor::Noise class

content.raw:
A dedicated class for sensor noise was added in pull request #647 and used in the GpsSensor. This class could be integrated with the ImuSensor and possibly others.

The tests could be updated as well, which would potentially help with the sporadic failures of [PhysicsEngines/ImuTest.EmptyWorldNoise](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-default-devel-quantal-amd64/lastCompletedBuild/testReport/%28root%29/PhysicsEngines_ImuTest/EmptyWorldNoise_0/).

A dedicated class for sensor noise was added in pull request #647 and used in the GpsSensor. This class could be integrated with the ImuSensor and possibly others.

The tests could be updated as well, which would potentially help with the sporadic failures of PhysicsEngines/ImuTest.EmptyWorldNoise.

values.title: Support building in catkin workspaces

content.raw:
It can be difficult to use both source builds and debian installs of gazebo on the same machine. Add in source builds of some dependencies (like sdformat and bullet) and it can be very tough to manage. One option for this is the use of [catkin workspaces](http://wiki.ros.org/catkin/workspaces). Although gazebo is not catkinized, it can be built using catkin with the `catkin_make_isolated` command.

To support catkin workspaces, we should add our dependencies to [package.xml](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/90d25760b578980af4a88eeb0ceb38d92265142e/package.xml?at=default). Additionally, we should consider making use of GNUInstallDirs optional, since the gazebo libraries are installed to `lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/`, while catkin expects everything to be in `lib`. I'm not sure if this should be a change to our gazebo cmake setup or a feature request for [catkin](https://github.com/ros/catkin) (cc-ing @wwoodall ).
content.html:
It can be difficult to use both source builds and debian installs of gazebo on the same machine. Add in source builds of some dependencies (like sdformat and bullet) and it can be very tough to manage. One option for this is the use of catkin workspaces. Although gazebo is not catkinized, it can be built using catkin with the catkin_make_isolated command.

To support catkin workspaces, we should add our dependencies to package.xml. Additionally, we should consider making use of GNUInstallDirs optional, since the gazebo libraries are installed to lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/, while catkin expects everything to be in lib. I'm not sure if this should be a change to our gazebo cmake setup or a feature request for catkin (cc-ing @wwoodall ).

values.title: Trouble with gzfactory spawn -f model.sdf

content.raw:
If you are in a folder that contains a file named model.sdf and attempt to spawn it with the command `gzfactory spawn -f model.sdf`, it will fail with the following error:
~~~
$ gzfactory spawn -f model.sdf
Error [parser_urdf.cc:2597] Unable to call parseURDF on robot model
Error [parser.cc:273] parse as old deprecated model file failed.
Error: SDF parsing the xml failed
~~~
This occurs because `sdf::findFile` finds `share/sdformat/1.4/model.sdf` before it finds the model.sdf in the local folder.

Using an absolute path works:
~~~
$ gzfactory spawn -f $PWD/model.sdf
Msg Waiting for master
Msg Connected to gazebo master @ http://127.0.0.1:11345
Msg Publicized address: 192.168.1.183
Spawning Model into default world.
~~~

Other filenames also work.
~~~
$ gzfactory spawn -f model-1_3.sdf
Msg Waiting for master
Msg Connected to gazebo master @ http://127.0.0.1:11345
Msg Publicized address: 192.168.1.183
Spawning Model into default world.
~~~

Presumably, other file names will have this same issue: `joint.sdf`, `light.sdf`, etc.

content.raw:
I was testing on my local machine the Wireless test suite since problems appeared frequently in jenkins. I used the gazebo branch (improve_serverfixture_msgs) which provide meaningful error messages. I found:

A failure in **WirelessTransmitter_TEST.TestInvalidFreq**

```
101: [ RUN      ] WirelessTransmitter_TEST.TestInvalidFreq

101: /root/gazebo/test/ServerFixture.hh:1003: Failure
101: Failed
101: ServerFixture timeout: max number of retries (1000) exceeded.
```

values.title: Missing cmake option to disable tests

content.raw:
most of the time for compiling gazebo is needed to compile
all the _TEST's. However, when installing directly to the system
there is no need to build all these development tests
which are ignored afterwards anyway.

It would be great to have a BUILD_TESTS option to the CMake scripts.
An alternative would be not to build the tests when CMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Release.
content.html:
most of the time for compiling gazebo is needed to compile all the _TEST's. However, when installing directly to the system there is no need to build all these development tests which are ignored afterwards anyway.

It would be great to have a BUILD_TESTS option to the CMake scripts. An alternative would be not to build the tests when CMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Release.

values.title: Use of shasum command in gzlog_TEST is not portable

content.raw: SHA1 sums are introduced in pull request #703 to simplify testing the expected values of long strings in [gzlog_TEST.cc](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/fe7cdb5db708b3488508a21c98e4321b5ffcb4e7/tools/gzlog_TEST.cc). The mechanism in this pull request is based on a pipe to the `shasum` command, which is available on Linux and OS X, but not on Windows. For portability, we should migrate this functionality to use boost instead of `shasum`.
content.html: SHA1 sums are introduced in pull request #703 to simplify testing the expected values of long strings in gzlog_TEST.cc. The mechanism in this pull request is based on a pipe to the shasum command, which is available on Linux and OS X, but not on Windows. For portability, we should migrate this functionality to use boost instead of shasum.

values.title: qt4 moc files are regenerated whenever cmake is invoked

content.raw:
This slows down rebuilding, since all the gui components must be re-compiled whenever cmake is invoked. To reproduce, do a normal build:
~~~
$ mkdir build
$ cd build
$ cmake ..
$ make
~~~
Then if you touch an unrelated CMakeLists.txt file, it will cause the moc files to be regenerated:
~~~
$ touch ../test/cmake/CMakeLists.txt
$ make
...
[  8%] Generating moc_qtpropertybrowser.cxx
[  8%] Generating moc_qtpropertymanager.cxx
[  9%] Generating moc_qteditorfactory.cxx
[  9%] Generating moc_qtvariantproperty.cxx
...
~~~
and then it rebuilds all the gui libraries and the executables that link against them.

values.title: Gazebo 1.9.1 does not cast shadows on COLLADA meshes

content.raw:
I rendered this image with Gazebo 1.9.1, ROS Hydro, and Ubuntu 12.04 LTS:

![No shadows cast on platform.](http://www.wunderkammerlab.com/examples/no-shadows-received.jpg)

The robot casts shadows, and the robot and terrain receive them, but the starting platform and the chair (both COLLADA meshes) do not, but should. I thought there might be a problem with my SketchUp-generated starting platform DAE file, so I put the chair from /opt/ros/hydro/share/gazebo_plugins/Media/models/chair/models/Chair.dae into the scene. It does not receive shadows, either.

I've worked around the problem by specifying a shadow-receiving material script for the starting platform in its SDF definition. However, I had to disable shadow casting for the platform in order to avoid significant self shadowing.
content.html:
I rendered this image with Gazebo 1.9.1, ROS Hydro, and Ubuntu 12.04 LTS:

The robot casts shadows, and the robot and terrain receive them, but the starting platform and the chair (both COLLADA meshes) do not, but should. I thought there might be a problem with my SketchUp-generated starting platform DAE file, so I put the chair from /opt/ros/hydro/share/gazebo_plugins/Media/models/chair/models/Chair.dae into the scene. It does not receive shadows, either.

I've worked around the problem by specifying a shadow-receiving material script for the starting platform in its SDF definition. However, I had to disable shadow casting for the platform in order to avoid significant self shadowing.

values.title: GpuRaySensor does not update time stamps if the scene is static

content.raw:
I tested some mapping stuff with a simulated quadrotor in Gazebo 1.9.1 coming with ROS hydro today. I am using a GPU ray sensor and the `libgazebo_ros_gpu_laser.so` plugin from gazebo_ros_pkgs.

When I switched the robot model to be static (for testing purposes, using the `<static>true</static>` tag in its description), I still got laser scans in ROS and also on gazebo's scan topic, but the time stamps have not been updated. If I changed the scene (e.g. by adding a block via the GUI), the time stamp was updated once but then remained fixed again.

The ROS plugin just takes the stamp from gazebo's `LaserScanStamped` message, so it's the GpuRaySensor that generates the wrong stamp. The RaySensor works fine even in a static scene.
content.html:
I tested some mapping stuff with a simulated quadrotor in Gazebo 1.9.1 coming with ROS hydro today. I am using a GPU ray sensor and the libgazebo_ros_gpu_laser.so plugin from gazebo_ros_pkgs.

When I switched the robot model to be static (for testing purposes, using the <static>true</static> tag in its description), I still got laser scans in ROS and also on gazebo's scan topic, but the time stamps have not been updated. If I changed the scene (e.g. by adding a block via the GUI), the time stamp was updated once but then remained fixed again.

The ROS plugin just takes the stamp from gazebo's LaserScanStamped message, so it's the GpuRaySensor that generates the wrong stamp. The RaySensor works fine even in a static scene.

values.title: Timeouts in tests

content.html:
The topic of discussion are loops like the following in our test suites:

int i = 0;
while (<some_check> && i < 100)
{
  common::Time::MSleep(100);
  ++i;
}
EXPECT_LT(i, 100);

Quoting Jose:

I'm not sure than we want to keep them into our unit tests. Use cases I can see:

  • Developing and running standalone test: if it stucks, the developer is just looking. CTRL+C. You know its not working.

  • Running test suite: it should be run from make test command, with implements proper timeout.

Maybe I'm missing other useful cases. Open for discussion to me.

values.title: Add option to visualize <link> reference frame axis.  visualize <collision> and <visual> frame axis.
Parallel Mechanisms

content.raw:
Quoting from the Gazebo Wiki

> While URDFs are a useful and standardized format in ROS, they are lacking many features and have not been updated to deal with the evolving needs of robotics. URDF can only specify the kinematic and dynamic properties of a single robot in isolation. URDF can not specify the pose of the robot itself within a world. **It is also not a universal description format since it cannot specify joint loops (parallel linkages), and it lacks friction and other properties.** Additionally, it cannot specify things that are not robots, such as lights, heightmaps, etc.*

We are trying to build a parallel mechanism where two joints have the same child but different parents or a closed loop with joints that form a parallel mechanism however when we load that model in Gazebo I get

```
Exception [Model.cc:658] can't have two joint with the same name

Error [Model.cc:153] LoadJoint Failed
```

Are parallel mechanisms supported in Gazebo 1.9.0?

If not, are there any plans on adding that functionality in the near future? Is such a functionality easily integrated in the current status of Gazebo?
content.html:
Quoting from the Gazebo Wiki

While URDFs are a useful and standardized format in ROS, they are lacking many features and have not been updated to deal with the evolving needs of robotics. URDF can only specify the kinematic and dynamic properties of a single robot in isolation. URDF can not specify the pose of the robot itself within a world. It is also not a universal description format since it cannot specify joint loops (parallel linkages), and it lacks friction and other properties. Additionally, it cannot specify things that are not robots, such as lights, heightmaps, etc.*

We are trying to build a parallel mechanism where two joints have the same child but different parents or a closed loop with joints that form a parallel mechanism however when we load that model in Gazebo I get

Exception [Model.cc:658] can't have two joint with the same name

Error [Model.cc:153] LoadJoint Failed

Are parallel mechanisms supported in Gazebo 1.9.0?

If not, are there any plans on adding that functionality in the near future? Is such a functionality easily integrated in the current status of Gazebo?

values.title: TracksDrivePlugin

content.raw:
Although various types of locomotion are supported in Gazebo with their appropriate ROS plugin, such as the DiffDrivePlugin, the SkidSteerPlugin and the VehiclePlugin, there is no plugin for track driven robots (which is a very common means of locomotion nowadays).

In this nature, we decided to build a plugin for Gazebo (and the appropriate ROS plugin) that supports tracks. However, in the velocity assignment, following the other plugins concept, we encountered (probably) the reason why noone has ever done this before.

There is no easy way to assign robot velocities to joint velocities because the actual tracks are contacting through a non-rigid material, transferring power through friction from the driving drum to the belt and finally to the floor.

We have thought of modelling the tracks using many small wheels that can have vertical displacement and share the same linear velocity with all the other wheels (differentially driven) but this would only be a partial solution as this is not an accurate model and the degrees of freedom of the robot would increase considerably making the simulation a hard task.

There is no SDF/URDF way of declaring tracks or non-rigid materials (for belts). Maybe this is the point were some decisions have to be made of how track-driven robots should be integrated in Gazebo/SDF/URDF/ROS. We would be willing to help in developing such functionality, if this is something planned or can be easily incorporated in Gazebo.
content.html:
Although various types of locomotion are supported in Gazebo with their appropriate ROS plugin, such as the DiffDrivePlugin, the SkidSteerPlugin and the VehiclePlugin, there is no plugin for track driven robots (which is a very common means of locomotion nowadays).

In this nature, we decided to build a plugin for Gazebo (and the appropriate ROS plugin) that supports tracks. However, in the velocity assignment, following the other plugins concept, we encountered (probably) the reason why noone has ever done this before.

There is no easy way to assign robot velocities to joint velocities because the actual tracks are contacting through a non-rigid material, transferring power through friction from the driving drum to the belt and finally to the floor.

We have thought of modelling the tracks using many small wheels that can have vertical displacement and share the same linear velocity with all the other wheels (differentially driven) but this would only be a partial solution as this is not an accurate model and the degrees of freedom of the robot would increase considerably making the simulation a hard task.

There is no SDF/URDF way of declaring tracks or non-rigid materials (for belts). Maybe this is the point were some decisions have to be made of how track-driven robots should be integrated in Gazebo/SDF/URDF/ROS. We would be willing to help in developing such functionality, if this is something planned or can be easily incorporated in Gazebo.

values.title: Simbody has trouble with pioneer2dx model and test

content.raw:

values.title: Setting position on heightmap creates offset between collision and visual

content.raw:
[Copyed from [answers.gazebosim.org](http://answers.gazebosim.org/question/4555/setting-position-on-heightmap-creates-offset/)]

When I set a position in my sdf for my heightmap I get an offset between collision and visual for the map as shown in the snapshot below. If I move the objects around I can see that the collision of the map has an offset. I'm able to move the objects into the mountains etc. All objects are affected by this not only the ones in the example snapshot. When I set the y position in the collision and visual to 0 the offset is gone. This error is a new behaviour that wasn't there 2 month ago(I haven't changed anything on the sdf files since july) so this is probably a bug... I'm not sure when this behaviour first occured because I haven't worked with an heightmap for quite a while...

We can assure some level of system independence using chroot, at leasts filesystem level, which probably can be a good starting point.

values.title: gzclient slow to load with many models due to shaders

content.raw: There were several comments on [drcsim issue 352](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/drcsim/issue/352/drc-practice-worlds-missing-models) ([here](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/drcsim/issue/352/drc-practice-worlds-missing-models#comment-6218044) and [here](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/drcsim/issue/352/drc-practice-worlds-missing-models#comment-6228033)) that the [drc_practice_task_2.world](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/drcsim/src/d1aee3900bc8bd783a80cc1d36600aee50f52410/drcsim_model_resources/worlds/drc_practice_task_2.world?at=default) takes a long time to load in gzclient. I have confirm that gzserver can load the world relatively quickly, but that gzclient can take about 2 minutes to start. I ran `valgrind --callgrind gzclient` and found `gazebo::rendering::RTShaderSystem::GenerateShaders` to occupy 50% of the call time during startup (here's a [screenshot of kcachegrind](https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/96660379/gazebo_GenerateShaders.png)).
content.html: There were several comments on drcsim issue 352 (here and here) that the drc_practice_task_2.world takes a long time to load in gzclient. I have confirm that gzserver can load the world relatively quickly, but that gzclient can take about 2 minutes to start. I ran valgrind --callgrind gzclient and found gazebo::rendering::RTShaderSystem::GenerateShaders to occupy 50% of the call time during startup (here's a screenshot of kcachegrind).

values.title: MOI visualization doesn't consider off-diagonal terms

content.html:
The MOI visualization introduced in pull request #745 does not consider off-diagonal terms. From COMVisual.cc:66-90:

  // Use principal moments of inertia to scale COM visual
  // TODO: rotate COM to match principal axes when product terms are nonzero
  // This can be done with Eigen, or with code from the following paper:
  // A Method for Fast Diagonalization of a 2x2 or 3x3 Real Symmetric Matrix
  // http://arxiv.org/abs/1306.6291v3

values.title: Gazebo URDF parser issues

content.raw:
Hi, 
I am trying to develop URDF for our robot(s). This is straighforward for the naked kinematics, and mostly works on Fuerte (gazebo 1.02) but is VERY annoying in Groovy and up. 

(Lots of gzserver crashes, then crazy searching in the log for the actual problem, and minute-long waiting until the nice very user-friendly gzserver actual decides to eventually maybe react to ctrl-c after is already dead. Whoever wrote the ctrl-c signal-handler in gzserver wastes hours of man-hours every day.)


1) Why can't the URDF parser output the line-number where a problem occured in the source file?

2) Why has the URDF to crash on ANY problem? Can't it just ignore any broken items in the URDF, and still (try to) load the rest of the robot?
That would help a lot.

3) On any crash, the full expanded XML is appended to the error, requiring to scroll-back manually a couple of thousand lines, at least for my robot.

4) The plugin documentation on the Gazebo site is crazy. It currently only lists the 1.9 plugin parameters, and the examples provided don't work on Groovy (1.5.0). This requires a lot of trial and error to try some parameters (e.g. <noise>), crash gzserver, scroll back, educated guess about what went bad this time, retry. If Hydro+1.9 is required, just TELL so on the website.
content.html:
Hi, I am trying to develop URDF for our robot(s). This is straighforward for the naked kinematics, and mostly works on Fuerte (gazebo 1.02) but is VERY annoying in Groovy and up.

(Lots of gzserver crashes, then crazy searching in the log for the actual problem, and minute-long waiting until the nice very user-friendly gzserver actual decides to eventually maybe react to ctrl-c after is already dead. Whoever wrote the ctrl-c signal-handler in gzserver wastes hours of man-hours every day.)

1) Why can't the URDF parser output the line-number where a problem occured in the source file?

2) Why has the URDF to crash on ANY problem? Can't it just ignore any broken items in the URDF, and still (try to) load the rest of the robot? That would help a lot.

3) On any crash, the full expanded XML is appended to the error, requiring to scroll-back manually a couple of thousand lines, at least for my robot.

4) The plugin documentation on the Gazebo site is crazy. It currently only lists the 1.9 plugin parameters, and the examples provided don't work on Groovy (1.5.0). This requires a lot of trial and error to try some parameters (e.g. <noise>), crash gzserver, scroll back, educated guess about what went bad this time, retry. If Hydro+1.9 is required, just TELL so on the website.

values.title: Physics Solution Checker (ie. NaN's)

content.raw:
Check the solution from each physics engine every iteration for incorrect values, such as NaN, inf values, etc.

This checker should be enabled/disabled from the command line. It should also output information to a log file.

A common culprit of returning NaN are the ODE joint parameter accessor function, such as `dJointGetHingeAngle`
content.html:
Check the solution from each physics engine every iteration for incorrect values, such as NaN, inf values, etc.

This checker should be enabled/disabled from the command line. It should also output information to a log file.

A common culprit of returning NaN are the ODE joint parameter accessor function, such as dJointGetHingeAngle

values.title: Installed ode headers have wrong path

content.raw: When gazebo 2.0's headers get installed, they're installed into /usr/include/gazebo-2.0/gazebo, but, the ode header files include "ode/filename.h" which is not in the header search path, since they are in the "ode" folder inside the "gazebo" folder. The ode headers should include other ode headers using the path: "gazebo/ode/filename.h" for them to be found.
content.html: When gazebo 2.0's headers get installed, they're installed into /usr/include/gazebo-2.0/gazebo, but, the ode header files include "ode/filename.h" which is not in the header search path, since they are in the "ode" folder inside the "gazebo" folder. The ode headers should include other ode headers using the path: "gazebo/ode/filename.h" for them to be found.

values.title: IMUSensor should get acceleration directly from physics engines

content.raw:
Currently [imu sensor does internal finite differencing to get velocity and acceleration](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/4321da81831c2c48c6ac8264ebf4cd57b5bba1ca/gazebo/sensors/ImuSensor.cc?at=default#cl-267).

We need to switch to [GetWorldLinearVel](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/4321da81831c2c48c6ac8264ebf4cd57b5bba1ca/gazebo/physics/Link.hh?at=default#cl-209) and [GetWorldAngularVel](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/4321da81831c2c48c6ac8264ebf4cd57b5bba1ca/gazebo/physics/Entity.hh?at=default#cl-145) for velocity; [GetWorldLinearAccel](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/4321da81831c2c48c6ac8264ebf4cd57b5bba1ca/gazebo/physics/Entity.hh?at=default#cl-155) and [GetWorldAngularAccel](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/4321da81831c2c48c6ac8264ebf4cd57b5bba1ca/gazebo/physics/Entity.hh?at=default#cl-163) for acceleration.
content.html:
Currently imu sensor does internal finite differencing to get velocity and acceleration.

We need to switch to GetWorldLinearVel and GetWorldAngularVel for velocity; GetWorldLinearAccel and GetWorldAngularAccel for acceleration.

values.title: common::get_sha1 doesn't always return 40 characters

content.html:
SHA1 hashes are supposed to be 20 bytes, with a hex string of 40 characters. Our common::get_sha1 function does not always return a string of 40 characters, however. The following addition to the test currently fails for about 20% of new hashes:

diff -r c03eacb07e69 gazebo/common/CommonIface_TEST.cc
--- a/gazebo/common/CommonIface_TEST.cc Sat Oct 12 12:49:34 2013 -0700
+++ b/gazebo/common/CommonIface_TEST.cc Tue Oct 15 02:38:46 2013 -0400
@@ -17,6 +17,8 @@

 #include <stdlib.h>
 #include <gtest/gtest.h>
+#include <string>
+#include <sstream>

 #include "gazebo/common/CommonIface.hh"

@@ -54,6 +56,15 @@
   computedSHA1 = common::get_sha1<std::string>(s);
   precomputedSHA1 = "da39a3ee5e6b4b0d3255bfef95601890afd80709";
   EXPECT_EQ(precomputedSHA1, computedSHA1);
+
+  // Compute a bunch of SHA1's to verify consistent length
+  for (unsigned i = 0; i < 100; ++i)
+  {
+    std::stringstream stream;
+    stream << i << '\n';
+    std::string sha = common::get_sha1<std::string>(stream.str());
+    EXPECT_EQ(sha.length(), 40u);
+  }
 }

 /////////////////////////////////////////////////

values.title: gazebo --help shows the gzserver information help

content.raw:
```
#!c++

~$ gazebo --help
gzserver -- Run the Gazebo server.

`gzserver` [options] <world_file>

Gazebo server runs simulation and handles commandline options, starts a Master, runs World update and sensor generation loops.

Options:
  -q [ --quiet ]                Reduce output to stdout.
  -h [ --help ]                 Produce this help message.
  -u [ --pause ]                Start the server in a paused state.
  -e [ --physics ] arg          Specify a physics engine (ode|bullet|simbody).
  -p [ --play ] arg             Play a log file.
  -r [ --record ]               Record state data.
  --record_encoding arg (=zlib) Compression encoding format for log data 
                                (zlib|bz2|txt).
  --record_path arg             Absolute path in which to store state data
  --seed arg                    Start with a given random number seed.
  --iters arg                   Number of iterations to simulate.
  --minimal_comms               Reduce the messages output by gzserver
  -s [ --server-plugin ] arg    Load a plugin.

gzclient -- Gazebo GUI Client

`gzclient` [options]

Gazebo GUI client which allows visualization and user interaction.

Options:
  -q [ --quiet ]          Reduce output to stdout.
  -h [ --help ]           Produce this help message.
```

values.title: Self-collide flag has lower priority over connected-ness of the two links

content.html:
According to the documentation of Link::SetSelfCollide(), the user might expect that the link can collide with any other links in the model.

/// \brief Set whether this body will collide with others in the
/// model.
/// \param[in] _collid True to enable collisions.
public: virtual void SetSelfCollide(bool _collide) = 0;

However, if two self-collidable links are connected by a joint, then they are excepted from collision checking: #!/osrf/gazebo/src/9ae1f91ee949a398ecc9a7599dedcc58cc035c63/gazebo/physics/ode/ODEPhysics.cc?at=default#cl-737

It would be nice if the document describe this or change the priority.
